Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Coupled Quantum Degrees of Freedom in Semiconductor Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Advances in material fabrication and experimental techniques have made it possible to create nanostructures whose quantum properties can be manipulated in controlled ways. These new capabilities have extended the ideas of quantum mechanics to structures larger than a single atom and are creating the potential for fundamentally new technologies for computation and communication. To determine the potential for such applications it is necessary to gain a fundamental understanding of interactions between the electrons in a nanostructure and other quantum mechanical properties of that structure. These quantum mechanical properties include the vibrations (known as phonons) and/or the magnetic properties of the nuclei (known as nuclear spin) in the nanostructure. This CAREER award supports a project that will carry out studies to gain this understanding. Research and education are seamlessly integrated throughout the project. To better educate the public, a nanoscience display will be constructed for the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, NJ. High school and undergraduate level research projects will be supported through involvement in the Partners in Science program and the REU program. The undergraduate Experimental Physics Seminar at Princeton will be reformatted to better emulate a realistic research environment. Students in this course will be required to form teams and propose an experiment that will take place throughout the remainder of the semester. This hands-on laboratory format is critical for teaching students how to operate in a realistic research setting and will foster cooperative learning. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows associated with this CAREER project will learn some of the most advanced experimental techniques used today in studying the physics of systems that are on the nanoscale or slightly larger.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This CAREER award supports a project focusing on studies of fundamental interactions between coupled quantum degrees of freedom in nanostructures. A series of experiments will be performed to probe electron-phonon coupling and electron-nuclear spin interactions in semiconductor quantum dots and multiple quantum dot systems. The understanding gained could have an impact on future technologies using quantum dots. Research and education are seamlessly integrated throughout the proposal. Activities include outreach to the general public, involving high school and undergraduate in research projects, and the development of a sophomore level seminar on experimental physics. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows associated with this CAREER project will learn low temperature experimental techniques, nanofabrication, and high frequency measurement; all skills that will provide an excellent preparation for future careers in academia or industrial research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project enabled the training of students in STEM disciplines. The training had a positive impact on students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate level.

At the high school level, I serve as a mentor for summer students in the Partners in Science Program. The Partners in Science program is managed by the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, NJ. The program aims to give high school students hands on research opportunities at local universities. Through this program, I have mentored three students: Moyukh Chatterjee, Shivang Patel, and James Ting. These students were assigned to summer projects involving the synthesis and characterization of Bi nanowires. They gained valuable training in the use of the scanning electron microscope, tube furnaces, and other basic laboratory equipment. James Ting and Shivang Patel are now undergraduate students at Yale. Moyukh Chatterjee is now an undergraduate student at MIT.

At the undergraduate level, I advise Princeton students as well as external REU students. Several Princeton undergraduate students have won prestigious awards. Yuliya Dovzhenko was awarded the Apker Prize in 2012. Christopher Quintana was the winner of the “2013 Best Engineering Physics Independent Work Award.” Ted Gundmundsen and Christopher Quintana were both awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships. My research group has advised three REU students. Patrick Herring’s project involved the assembly of our InAs nanowire reactor. Luthfia Syarbaini synthesized ZnO nanowires and Greg Prisco synthesized Bi nanowires. All of my REU students have gone on to graduate school. Patrick Herring (a NSF graduate fellow) is in his final year of graduate school at MIT. Luthfia Syarbaini is a graduate student at Purdue. Greg Prisco is a graduate student at U. Penn.

At the graduate level, NSF funds were used to support graduate students Loren Alegria, Michael Schroer, and Ke Wang. These students published several technical journal articles related to the NSF award.
